message: I usually program using a file with some useful functions that I made some years ag, but I don't use anyframework yet
For web projects, yep. Kohana3 at the moment, though I will switch to ZF2 when its released.
could you tell me pros and cons of frameworks?
Hello everyone =)
I currently use CodeIgniter for all my new PHP projects. It's lightweight, easy to use, and easy to ignore if you just want to use the MVC portion.
The pros are probably functionality, speed of development and reusability, the cons are baggage and some constraints

Work on and use Chisimba. It has a lot of modules if you want functionality, but you can ignore the modules you don't need and just use its MVC method. Has editiable canvas, JSON templates, and a whole lot of APIs.

I use chisimba framework, which uses the MVC paradigm and has a powerful module management feature, allowing people to (un)install modules and configure sites based on need..check chisimba.com for more...
I use Nette Framework.
I am using chisimba framework.
@miniunis +1 !
I would highly suggest CodeIgniter 2 hosted on BitBucket(I think?) There are a lot of good improvements and I am updating all my website's and client websites to run on it in the next few months.
I'm currently using a homebrewn framework which lends some it's design and conceptual idea's from ZF and Code Igniter. I'm planning on checking out Symfony reloaded soon.
i use zend framework
I'm using solarphp its really handy
I've been using Codeigniter for years. Made a quick webapp this week without it and felt lost. Now that I understand the MVC setup, I'll never go back.

@tjmckenzie I had to fix a classmate's code that was mixed in with HTML recently for an assignment and I almost started crying. The professor wants us to embed our code into the HTML and it makes me sick since learning CI, so I don't do it.
i use Codeigniter, it's fast, simple and you can get under the hood easily, and doesn't require Terminal to make new projects like ZF or cakePHP
Codeigniter, ftw. :)
I use Kohana 3 because chicks dig guys who use that framework.
I'm currently high on Lithium - http://lithify.me/ It just works, fast :) For bigger projects I'm also a fanboy of http://www.typo3.org/ that is a CMS with a framework and tons of extensions
use ZendFramework.  Anyone use Yii?  I would be interested in hearing about your experience with it.
well Yii looks promising but leaks the advertising and marketing, cakePHP ,ZF got lots of them, i never got to use Yii but i would love to hear what's different between it and other Frameworks
i use CakePHP , it's best framework
3 weeks ago I decided to use a PHP Framework for the first time, was torn between cake and CodeIgniter. I ultimately went with CI, and am liking quite a bit.

I am using Yii and personally think it is a great framework. The problem is that there isn't such a big community as the project is only about 2 years old. Anyways, you can easily add Zend modules/extensions (and not only that) if that is a feature you are searching for.
KohanaPHP FTW!
I just built LinkChirp.com in CodeIgniter and I loved it. Very easy to pickup and learn but quite powerful without feeling bloated.

I think using a framework is entirely dependent on the project. I have used Zend, Cake, Lithium, Symfony, and a few others. Zend is the only one I have really liked, because of its power, but this power comes with a lot of bloat. I have a framework I built for PHP 5.3 that I use for building APIs because it is lightweight. So the choice is just which is right for your project.
i don't use much but.. if its required i would prefer codeignitor or zend
Hello guys. I tried out Code Igniter over the weekend for a sample application - really liked it! greetings from switzerland..
Also fuelphp (by one of the CI contributors) is new and interesting
Codeigniter 2 is awesome!
Looks cool - really like the logo ;)
I started to work on a new little site today. I use glue for dispatching and h2o as templating language.

I've used Zend, CodeIgniter (since around 1.6.1 and CI2) and Kohana. Kohana is the best framework I used so far, the problem is that the documentation sucks big time (you regularly have to read the code itself to understand how to make something).
@liveink : i also developed a CMS called Egypt i think you need to see it  http://blazeeboy.github.com/Codeigniter-Egypt/
Nope. Frameworks aren't for me, unless I really need to.
If it is a big project I always use Codeigniter, if it is a simple page, without functionality I code everything without a framework.

I never used to use a framework but i am coming around. Codeignitor is excellent especially when you use the API - http://net.tutsplus.com/tutorials/php/working-with-restful-services-in-codeigniter-2/
I use symfony, is great ;)
Zend Framework here also.
Yes, I work w/ ZF

I used to always code without a framework but started playing with codeigniter a few months ago. Now working on a new startup and decided to use codeigniter. Little bit of a learning curve but getting hooked.
+1 codeigniter + rest
Would you recommend somebody learning PHP for the first time to use a framework or code things without to start with ?
@TSJ Learn the basics of PHP first before looking at a framework. Frameworks wont make sense to you unless you have a solid base

Yes, I use a framework for just about anything. Unless the project aim is such that it *will never* require more than a couple lines of code, I see no reason not to use a framework from scratch and get all the benefits that comes along with it.

I second @TSJ.  Learn php first then framework. I've been coding in php for nearly 10 years and still have a hard time getting my mind around the framework from time to time since I just started learning Codeigniter recently. Still, not going back to straight php if I can help it.
I use symfony
Whatever you do - don't get stuck with PHP. Eg Ruby can be used for more tasks. Eg you can write applications keeping state in memory etc. If you think about such topics PHP is a lock in.
what you mean with 'keeping state in memory'?
I use Symfony as well....
If you wanna start with a php framework, I recommend CodeIgniter. It's very easy to learn and well documented (IMO, is the best documented).
Do frameworks significantly reduce development time ?
@TSJ also depends on what you want to do, larger projects or projects that use the same code over and over to render content
@TSJ for larger projects I would say yes
@TSJ Frameworks also tend to help you get better organized, which really helps when it comes time to maintain the code.
I've used CakePHP a lot. They have decent documentation and its nice to work with for the most part.
I use CodeIgniter as PHP Framework and Rails otherwise.
@OyoKooN Yeah, I'm really starting to love CodeIgniter. That framework is really doing some great things.
@CrowderSoup If I can help you ;)
@OyoKooN Sure, I'll DM you if I need any help :)
I use FuelPHP or Kohana.

I just wrote up a piece comparing the communities of the top PHP frameworks: http://vvv.tobiassjosten.net/php/communities-comparison-for-php-frameworks - is that something you consider when considering a foundation for your next project?
I use CakePHP but looking foward to build my own :)
now i try to learn CakePHP :D, interest with this framework :D
